sentences.sentence: Readers respond to an opinion essay about tenure.
Also: The C.D.C.

director and boosters; Joe Biden and Donald Trump; the spending bill.To the Editor:Re “To Save Tenure, We Need to Change It,” by Molly Worthen (Opinion guest essay, Sunday Review, Sept. 26):Professor Worthen correctly identifies narrow specialization as the main impediment to achieving the essential goals of undergraduate education.

Linking the job security of professors to publishing alone devalues teaching and imposes barriers to learning.If we were to create colleges anew, with current and future generations in mind, students would build meaningful paths of inquiry to confront pressing global problems directly.
A college designed to achieve that result would emphasize experimentation, creativity and entrepreneurial energy.

It would be guided by the challenges we seek to meet, rather than the reproduction of disciplinary boundaries.Tenure does the opposite, prioritizing specialization so ferociously that the academy loses sight of its very purpose ᅳ to foster a citizenry able to collaboratively solve the world's most bedeviling problems.Ed WingenbachAmherst, Mass.The writer is the president of Hampshire College.To the Editor:Kudos to Molly Worthen for revisiting tenure, its historical origins and the different ways faculty and administrators are affected by it, as well as for her call to challenge what she properly calls “academia's culture of extreme risk aversion.”But I was extremely disappointed that in an otherwise comprehensive assessment, Dr. Worthen did not address the presence or absence of faculty of color.

Yet, the indisputable authority and stability of tenured professors are of the greatest consequence for the future of diversity, equity and inclusion in academia.We need to recognize that our universities have not done all they are capable of doing either to hire adequate numbers of faculty of color or to promote the existing faculty of color to the highest ranks of the tenured.Now more than ever, faculty diversity matters!Alejandro LugoPark Forest, Ill.The writer has taught anthropology and ethnic and racial studies for three decades at several American universities.To the Editor:Kudos to Molly Worthen for her guest essay.

There is one aspect to the discussion, however, that is already affecting the long-term future of tenure: the marketplace.Although specialization of a topic may be rewarded in the publication of scholarly articles in professional journals, university presses need to acquire books that not only disseminate knowledge but also sell enough copies to break even and pay the bills.With the severe collapse of library sales in the last 50 years, university presses must acquire books that sell.
University presses are already declining to publish books with poor markets, no matter how worthy the scholarship, because they can no longer afford to do so.

And so faculty members without a book contract in academic departments for which the book is key will not receive tenure.The impact of the marketplace is real and will affect the tenure process for years to come.George F. ThompsonStaunton, Va.The writer is a book publisher.To the Editor:Molly Worthen's guest essay introduces some fair observations on how to modernize universities' approach to tenure, but misses a few simple structural changes that institutions can make to help improve the classroom experience for everyone.At Barnard College, where I am president, our professors have tenure at both Barnard, which is focused on in-classroom experiences, and Columbia University, with the resources of a large Ivy League research-focused institution.

This creates a balanced expectation for Barnard faculty members to pursue their own research while ensuring that they also serve and involve the students they teach.More broadly, honors programs at many colleges and universities tend to prioritize close mentorship relationships between undergraduates and faculty.
There is room to expand this approach where professors invest personally in their students' success.Higher education can and should reflect on the tenure process.

However, structural changes that more closely align the experience for students and our cherished faculty will be what allows us to truly live the life of the mind.Sian Leah BeilockNew York'Disheartened' by the C.D.C.

Director's Decision on BoostersTo the Editor:Re “States Rush to Roll Out Booster Shot Programs for Eligible Americans” (front page, Sept. 25):As a former chair of the Advisory Committee on Immunization Practices, I am disheartened by the C.D.C.

director's reversal, within hours, of the committee's recommendation that those with occupational exposure to Covid-19 should not receive boosters at this time.Not only is the director's decision wrong on the merits and unsupported by the science, as made clear by the careful review of data and deliberations of the committee, but it undermines the longstanding independent, transparent, and highly ethical and valuable process of making vaccination policy in the United States.Finally, the director's decision to include health care workers, teachers and other frontline workers among those eligible for the booster will make implementation of booster doses far more complicated, risking the successful delivery of the boosters to those in the recommended categories ᅳ over 65, in long-term care facilities and with underlying medical conditions ᅳ who have real need of them.Nancy M. BennettNew YorkThe writer is a professor of medicine and public health sciences at the University of Rochester School of Medicine and Dentistry.Biden Is No TrumpTo the Editor:Re “The UnTrump Presidency Slams Into Trumpness,” by Frank Bruni (Opinion, nytimes.com, Sept. 22):While it may not exactly be campaigning in poetry and governing in prose, as President Biden reminds no one of Barack Obama or Bill Clinton for his capacity to elevate and captivate, the real lesson learned is that the act of leading this country is hard.Mr.

Biden faces a wholly uncooperative Republican opposition that combines obstinacy with fiction in thwarting his intentions; an Afghan government that crumbled instantaneously when challenged and greatly amplified the president's miscalculation; a large portion of the American public that refuses to believe in the power of the vaccine; and a border that serves as a daily reminder that much of the world is in chaos that we can do little to alter.That is not to say all has been handled with dexterity, the French-Australian sub fiasco a black eye in diplomacy.
And, yes, the optics certainly superficially invite comparison of the president and his predecessor.
But Mr. Biden and Donald Trump in the same sentence?
I think not.Mr.
Trump's animosities, coupled with his incompetence, invited disaster at every turn.

Mr. Biden's morality and lifelong belief in the foundation of government at least give us reason to hope for a better tomorrow.And there is poetry in not having Mr. Trump there to remind us how easy it is to squander the riches of a democracy.Robert S. NussbaumGreat Barrington, Mass.A $3.5 Trillion BargainTo the Editor:Re “It's Not Really a $3.5 Trillion Bill,” by Peter Coy (Opinion, nytimes.com, Sept. 22):Americans have trouble passing anything because they only see big numbers, not the per capita cost divided among 330 million people over 10 years.
This hugely beneficial bill averages $3 a day, or the cost of a cup of coffee or a McDonald's Happy Meal.
And that is an average.
The rich pay more and the middle class and poor pay less.
For millions, this money would be their salary in a job with a future.And what do we get?

Roads, bridges that don't fall down, electric car charging stations, the cleanest air in generations, universal preschool, expanded child care benefits, and for those who care, a habitable world for their grandchildren.Seems like a bargain to me.Deborah MoranHoustonPHOTO:    (PHOTOGRAPH BY Illustration by Shoshana Schultz; photographs by Allen Green/Getty Images and Ollie Noonan Jr./The Boston Globe, via Getty Images FOR THE NEW YORK TIMES)
